learning_outcomes.description: Justify professional decisions by appealing to relevant ethical and legal frameworks and take responsibility for your decisions.
Provide comprehensive, patient-centred medication management plans to ensure the safe, effective and judicious use of medicines.
Communicate effectively in a range of pharmacy practice contexts.
Improve use of medicines by intervening at a system level within a health care setting.
Provide patient-centred, socially and culturally appropriate care in a range of pharmacy practice contexts.
Assess ambulatory conditions and recommend appropriate management approaches, including pharmacological, non-pharmacological and referral options where appropriate.
Demonstrate teamwork behaviours as appropriate to the roles of pharmacists within health care teams, including oral and written communication.
Prescribe medications in accordance with current jurisdiction-specific legislation, scope of practice and professional guidance.
Reflect on your knowledge and capabilities as part of continuing professional development.

assessments.task_description:
Write a critical reflection on your perceived gaps in your knowledge and skills when comparing against the Australian Pharmacy Council (APC) Performance Outcomes domains. The purpose of the reflection is to develop a plan to address these gaps during the course and identify milestones to demonstrate that you have addressed the identified gaps in your knowledge and skills.

See the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site for more information and the marking criteria. In the case of a failing mark for this reflection, feedback will be provided and resubmission permitted.

This assessment contributes to the following domains:

  • Primary Domain marks: L&M
  • Secondary Domain marks: PiP, RIE

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assessment item will be submitted using ePortfolio, which can be accessed via the PHRM4102 Learn.UQ page
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: Exams submitted after the end of the submission time will incur a late penalty.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
22/09/2025

This exam will occur during your Stream 2 Tutorial
assessments.task_description:
This is an in-class invigilated exam. A physical AMH book is permitted to be used in the exam.

This exam includes demonstration of therapeutic knowledge and management of an integrated case focussing on written communication with other health professionals, and application of legal and ethical responsibilities.

The exam will consist of various question types including multiple choice and multiple answer, as well as written short response.

See the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site for more information and the marking criteria.

The exam will be undertaken via the Inspera eAssessment platform (as will any deferred exams). Go to the Inspera Assessment Information page link to navigate to the Library Services web page which provides further information on: how to access Inspera, on-campus invigilated exams in Inspera, device requirements, familiarisation opportunities, submitting assessment and access to the Student Laptop Scheme and short-term laptop-loans.

Link for Inspera Assessment Information page:

Inspera Assessment (Original) - eLearning - University of Queensland

This assessment contributes to the following domains:

  • Primary Domain marks: PiP, C&C, PEx
assessments.submission_guidelines: This exam will be completed using your own device (laptop) requiring an exam-safe browser to access Inspera. Alternatively, you can use one of the desktop computers in the dispensing lab, where the exam will be held.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: Exams submitted after the end of the submission time will incur a late penalty.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This is a team assignment with a team mark awarded. Tutorial groups will be split into teams of 4 to 5 students. Each student team will select a real-world problem to which they must apply systems level thinking to develop a systems level solution. The cases will be posted on Learn.UQ (Blackboard) during week 5. 

Students must develop a poster of their systems level solution to the assigned problem. Each team of students will then present a 5-minute presentation of their case. The expectation is each student will speak during the presentation.

Guidance on how to structure the poster and oral presentation, and the marking rubrics for each will be provided on the PHRM4102 Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site. Marks for this item will be adjusted using Peer Assessment of groupwork.

This assessment contributes to the following domains:

  • Primary Domain marks: RIE
  • Secondary Domain marks: C&C, L&M

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

The poster presentation will be recorded and retained as per university policy. The recording will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed if required for the purposes of moderation of marking; provision of feedback to the student; and/or re-marking following a successful re-mark application.
assessments.submission_guidelines: One team member will submit the team poster via the link provided in the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Write a follow up written reflection on how you addressed your perceived gaps in knowledge and skills including outcomes to support this. For your knowledge and skills gaps that you were not able to address, what you will do to address these as you transition through your intern year.

See the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site for more information and the marking criteria. In the case of a failing mark for this reflection, feedback will be provided and resubmission permitted.

This assessment contributes to the following domains:

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.

assessments.task_description:
This is a team assignment with a team mark awarded. Tutorial groups will be split into teams of 4 to 5 students. Each student team will be assigned an integrated case for which they will outline medication-related problems and their resolution. The assigned cases will be posted on Learn.UQ (Blackboard) during week 9. 

Each team of students will be expected to present a 10-minute presentation of their case. The expectation is each student will speak during the presentation.

Guidance regarding how to structure the presentation and marking rubric will be provided on Learn.UQ (Blackboard). Marks for this item will be adjusted using Peer Assessment of groupwork. You will have the opportunity to ask questions about your cases and the presentation during the tutorials in weeks 10 and 11.

This assessment contributes to the following domains:

  • Primary Domain marks: PEx
  • Secondary Domain marks: C&C, L&M, RIE

The Grand Round Presentation will be recorded and retained as per university policy. The recording will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed if required for the purposes of moderation of marking; provision of feedback to the student; and/or re-marking following a successful re-mark application. 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: One team member will submit the team slide deck via the link provided in the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The oral examination will assess knowledge and application to identify medication related problems and discuss therapeutic decision making in choosing options to resolve the medication related problems.

This will be an oral VIVA of a patient case during the end of semester examination period.

The viva will be 30 minutes in duration including 15 minutes reading and preparation time. During the preparation and reading time only, you will have access to the AMH and eTGs. You will need to bring your own physical hard copy of AMH.

After 15 minutes you will commence the oral examination, discussing the medication related problem(s) you have identified and plan to resolve these with the examiner who will then also ask you questions about your case and recommendations.

This assessment contributes to the following domains:

  • Primary Domain marks: C&C, PEx
  • Secondary Domain marks: PiP

This oral viva will be recorded and retained as per university policy. The recording will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed if required for the purposes of moderation of marking; provision of feedback to the student; and/or re-marking following a successful re-mark application.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The PHRM4102 OSCE oral exam will consist of 2 OSCE stations at which students demonstrate a range of skills and knowledge including:

  • Managing a pharmacy presentation: 10-minute station. Students will provide patient-centred care for a consumer presentation. This may take the form of a symptom or product request, or prescription presentation, and will require demonstration of information gathering skills, clinical and scope-of-practice judgements, and counselling skills.
  • Challenging communication: 5-minute station. Students will engage in a challenging verbally communication scenario, potentially involving a patient, customer, or other healthcare provider. The focus of this station is on demonstrating advanced communication skills.

Further descriptions, guidance and marking rubrics for these stations will be available on the PHRM4102 Blackboard site.

Your own physical AMH book is permitted to be used in the exam

The PHRM4102 OSCE stations will be based on concepts, medicine disease states, medicines, scenarios, skills and knowledge you have attained during your pharmacy degree to date. 

This assessment contributes to the following domains:

  • Primary Domain marks: C&C, PEx
  • Secondary Domain marks: PiP

This OSCE oral exam will be recorded and retained as per university policy. The recording will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed if required for the purposes of moderation of marking; provision of feedback to the student; and/or re-marking following a successful re-mark application.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 5 To Week 12(25 Aug - 26 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Stream 1 Tutorials - Advanced Medication Management

Attend your timetabled 3 hour Tutorial on Tuesday each week.

These tutorials focus on managing complex patient presentations and medication regimens in various clinical settings. Complete the Stream 1 UQ Extend active online learning for the week before coming to the tutorial to test and refresh your knowledge on some relevant practice areas that will be explored.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Stream 1 Tutorials - Advanced Medication Management Attend your timetabled 3 hour Tutorial on Tuesday each week. These tutorials focus on managing complex patient presentations and medication regimens in various clinical settings. Complete the Stream 1 UQ Extend active online learning for the week before coming to the tutorial to test and refresh your knowledge on some relevant practice areas that will be explored.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 5 To Week 13(25 Aug - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Stream 2 Tutorials - Professional Responsibilities

Attend your timetabled 2 hour Tutorial on Monday each week.

These tutorials focus on developing and challenging your professional responsibilities, particularly focussing on communication and ethics in various settings. Complete the Stream 2 UQ Extend active online learning for the week before coming to the tutorial to test and refresh your knowledge on some relevant areas that will be explored.
learning_activities.topic_description: Stream 2 Tutorials - Professional Responsibilities Attend your timetabled 2 hour Tutorial on Monday each week. These tutorials focus on developing and challenging your professional responsibilities, particularly focussing on communication and ethics in various settings. Complete the Stream 2 UQ Extend active online learning for the week before coming to the tutorial to test and refresh your knowledge on some relevant areas that will be explored.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 5 To Week 13(25 Aug - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Stream 3 Tutorials - Extending Pharmacy Practice

Attend your timetabled 2 hour Tutorial on Monday each week.

These tutorials focus on expanding the scope of your role as a pharmacist, including thinking in and implementing changes as a system level. Complete the Stream 3 UQ Extend active online learning for the week before coming to the tutorial to test and refresh your knowledge on some relevant areas that will be explored.


Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L07, L08

learning_activities.topic:
Final Lecture

The final lecture is a UQ Pharmacy classic event that celebrates the end of your studies within the Pharmacy program. See Learn.UQ for information on this event.
